Maximum Places
50
HESA Cost Centres
Biosciences
Rationale
This module specification has been reviewed and updated to bring in-line with current requirements. There have been no changes to mode of delivery, syllabus, assessments etc.
Blurb
Overview
This module will prepare students for their MSc research project. Students will work in collaboration with their research project supervisor to devise a plan of work aimed at developing the knowledge and skills that will be required for the MSc research project. Students are expected to work independently, guided by regular meetings with their supervisor. Students will create a portfolio in which they will compile evidence of all work carried out and reflections on this work. Students will also write a literature review on a topic closely related to their planned research project, and a grant proposal. By the end of this module, students will be prepared to carry out their MSc research project.
Educational Aims
To prepare students for their MSc research project module, this module will give students the opportunity to gain the knowledge and the skills specific to their project area.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will prepare students for their MSc research project. Students will work under the guidance of their research project supervisor to acquire the knowledge and skills they will need for their MSc research project. Students will work in collaboration with their supervisor to identify skills and knowledge essential for their MSc research project and to devise a plan of work to address these. Students are expected to work independently through their plan of work, with guidance provided by their supervisor at regular meetings. Students will create a reflective portfolio of work which will highlight how and where the skills have been developed. Students will perform a literature search and write a literature review based on their project area, as well as write a grant proposal. Upon completion of this module, students will progress on to their MSc research project module.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus includes the following elements: planning and designing a research project, identification of skills required, undertaking a literature survey and preparing a project grant proposal. At the start of the module, students with the help of their research project supervisor, will identify which skills they will need to acquire to complete a successful research project in their chosen pathway. Students will then agree a series of tasks to develop the necessary skills. Students will be expected to keep a reflective log of their activities and demonstrate that they have achieved the required level of expertise with a portfolio or work which is presented regularly to the supervisor for inspection.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Lecture
Description: A lecture will be delivered at the start of the module, to introduce the module and the assessments.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Direct Supervision
Description: Students will have regular meetings with their supervisor. Initially these meetings will be used to identify the knowledge and skills students need to acquire for their MSc research project. The meetings will then be used for the supervisor to provide feedback and guidance on work performed for this module. The teaching staff on this module varies each year as the research projects being undertaken change in accordance with student interests.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Practical
Description: The type of practical work will relate to the planned MSc research project and will typically involve periods of practical training either in the laboratory, in the field, or via computer based work. This work will be guided by project supervisor.
Attendance Recorded: No

Self-directed learning
Description: Students will work independently through a plan of work developed with their supervisor. The nature of this work will reflect the MSc research project, and may include reading of textbooks and literature, reading of protocols and manuals, viewing of online resources, engagement with remote training materials.

Curriculum 2021 hallmarks addressed:
- Research connected teaching. Students are supervised by a research supervisor, and carry out work to prepare for their MSc research project.
- Active learning. Students will develop and practise practical skills required for their MSc research project.
- Confidence. Students will work independently to develop skills and knowledge to allow them to approach their MSc research project with confidence

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
Literature Review
A review article on a topic related to the research project, that is critically informed by the scientific literature. This is an authentic assessment: students write according to the author guidelines of a peer-reviewed journal of their choice, thus the word limit for this assignment is quite wide to reflect differing journal requirements, with a 10% +/- margin around the journal specified word count allowed.
Marked by supervisor and second assessor.

Grant Proposal
A plan for a research project written in the form of a short grant proposal.
Marked by supervisor and second assessor.

Portfolio.
A portfolio showing how skills have been acquired, against a plan of work created in collaboration with the supervisor.
Marked by supervisor.

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given for each assessment and will have the same format and content as the original assessment. Resits will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 50%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.
Pass mark is 50.

Curriculum 2021 hallmarks addressed:
- Research-connected teaching. Students will write a literature review and a grant proposal related to their MSc research project.
- Authentic Assessment. Students will write a literature review and a grant proposal.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Admin

Maximum Places
50
HESA Cost Centres
Biosciences
Rationale
This module specification has been reviewed and updated to bring in-line with current requirements. There have been no changes to mode of delivery, syllabus, assessments etc.
Blurb
Overview
This module will prepare students for their MSc research project. Students will work in collaboration with their research project supervisor to devise a plan of work aimed at developing the knowledge and skills that will be required for the MSc research project. Students are expected to work independently, guided by regular meetings with their supervisor. Students will create a portfolio in which they will compile evidence of all work carried out and reflections on this work. Students will also write a literature review on a topic closely related to their planned research project, and a grant proposal. By the end of this module, students will be prepared to carry out their MSc research project.
Educational Aims
To prepare students for their MSc research project module, this module will give students the opportunity to gain the knowledge and the skills specific to their project area.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will prepare students for their MSc research project. Students will work under the guidance of their research project supervisor to acquire the knowledge and skills they will need for their MSc research project. Students will work in collaboration with their supervisor to identify skills and knowledge essential for their MSc research project and to devise a plan of work to address these. Students are expected to work independently through their plan of work, with guidance provided by their supervisor at regular meetings. Students will create a reflective portfolio of work which will highlight how and where the skills have been developed. Students will perform a literature search and write a literature review based on their project area, as well as write a grant proposal. Upon completion of this module, students will progress on to their MSc research project module.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus includes the following elements: planning and designing a research project, identification of skills required, undertaking a literature survey and preparing a project grant proposal. At the start of the module, students with the help of their research project supervisor, will identify which skills they will need to acquire to complete a successful research project in their chosen pathway. Students will then agree a series of tasks to develop the necessary skills. Students will be expected to keep a reflective log of their activities and demonstrate that they have achieved the required level of expertise with a portfolio or work which is presented regularly to the supervisor for inspection.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Lecture
Description: A lecture will be delivered at the start of the module, to introduce the module and the assessments.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Direct Supervision
Description: Students will have regular meetings with their supervisor. Initially these meetings will be used to identify the knowledge and skills students need to acquire for their MSc research project. The meetings will then be used for the supervisor to provide feedback and guidance on work performed for this module. The teaching staff on this module varies each year as the research projects being undertaken change in accordance with student interests.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Practical
Description: The type of practical work will relate to the planned MSc research project and will typically involve periods of practical training either in the laboratory, in the field, or via computer based work. This work will be guided by project supervisor.
Attendance Recorded: No

Self-directed learning
Description: Students will work independently through a plan of work developed with their supervisor. The nature of this work will reflect the MSc research project, and may include reading of textbooks and literature, reading of protocols and manuals, viewing of online resources, engagement with remote training materials.

Curriculum 2021 hallmarks addressed:
- Research connected teaching. Students are supervised by a research supervisor, and carry out work to prepare for their MSc research project.
- Active learning. Students will develop and practise practical skills required for their MSc research project.
- Confidence. Students will work independently to develop skills and knowledge to allow them to approach their MSc research project with confidence

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
Literature Review
A review article on a topic related to the research project, that is critically informed by the scientific literature. This is an authentic assessment: students write according to the author guidelines of a peer-reviewed journal of their choice, thus the word limit for this assignment is quite wide to reflect differing journal requirements, with a 10% +/- margin around the journal specified word count allowed.
Marked by supervisor and second assessor.

Grant Proposal
A plan for a research project written in the form of a short grant proposal.
Marked by supervisor and second assessor.

Portfolio.
A portfolio showing how skills have been acquired, against a plan of work created in collaboration with the supervisor.
Marked by supervisor.

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given for each assessment and will have the same format and content as the original assessment. Resits will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 50%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.
Pass mark is 50.

Curriculum 2021 hallmarks addressed:
- Research-connected teaching. Students will write a literature review and a grant proposal related to their MSc research project.
- Authentic Assessment. Students will write a literature review and a grant proposal.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Admin
